Rule Breakers
Recommended
For Expulsion
After a series of hearings this
week, the following action was
taken by the Dormitory Student
Resident Council: for violation
of the rules concerning the hours
women are allowed in the dormitories, two students were recommended to Dr. q. Wilson Shaffer, Dean of the Homewood
Schools, for immediate expulsion
from the dormitories.
The Dean concurred and the
students will be removed from
the dormitories as soon as possible.

74 Frosh Pledge
As Rushing Closes
Formal rushing ended Saturday night as 174 freshmen pledged Hopkins fraternities Sunday afternoon, according to IFB president Gil Decker.
Of these, 95% pledged to the 13 IFB fraternities
while the remainder, 5%, pledged Zeta Beta Tau. ,The
number of pledges represents 45% of the freshman class
as compared to 39% in 1956 and 50% in 1955.
This year's pledges are in the alphabetical order of
their fraternity:

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, NOV. IS, 1957

IGY Chairman Dr. Kaplan
To Speak In Shriver Hall
Dr. Joseph Kaplan, chairman
of the United States commission
in the International Geophysical
Year, will speak in Shriver Hall,
November 20, at 8:00 p.m. under the co-sponsorship of the
Hopkins chapter of the Society
of American Military Engineers
and its Baltimore parent organization.
Dr. Kaplan's background in
science includes membership and
affiliation with a number of
scientific organizations. He received his B. S., M. A., and
Ph. D. degrees at Johns Hopkins
in 1924, 1926, and 1927, respectively. He continued his studies
on a research fellowship at
Princeton in 1927 and later at
the 'University of California rose
from
assistant professor of
physics to full professor in 1940.

by the War Department for
exceptional civilian service and
received the Achievement award
from Tau Delta Phi. His contributions to science include the
discovery of the laboratory production of auroral spectrum and
of the light of the night sky.

American Astronomy Society,

the Pacific, the Society for
Research on Meteorites, the
Optical Society of America, the
American Meteorological Society, the "Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, Tau Beta Pi,

Correspondence
Dear Editors:
I think it would be a ridiculous
proposal to assure every student
who goes out for a school team
a time to play. I read in the
last sports editorial "many who
would not consider . . . would
be more willing if they were
assured of playing." These are
the people we don't want anyhow.
What we want is the fellow
who goes out for the love of the
game and the will to win, with-out guarantees that he play a
certain amount or other assurances.
If there were guarantees, every
Tom, Joe, and Harry, who
wanted to look good in front of
the women, would go out for the
team, throw in a few halfhearted days of practice, and
presto, he's in (according to that
system of guarantees).
Think of the fix that would
put our team in. People who fear

that they won't play can always
join an independent or fraternal
team anyway.
If you try to substitute the
need to win for a need of total
participation, then you are exchanging a trained team of men
who mean business for a bunch
of babies, and turning what may
have been a good, tough, wellplayed ball game into a ludicrous
farce. When you take the emphasis off the need to win, you
cut -Clown the mean, fighting,
rocky spirit of the team. If you
don't play to win, why keep
score? Can you imagine the
cheer of Hopkins changing from
"Let's Beat F & M" to "Let's
Play F & M"?
To me, winning means a lot. A
tough, ferocious, rugged, punching, fiery game makes winning
even sweeter.
Martin G. Lichtenstein

Two weeks ago, two features
writers attended—rather crashed
—a press reception given at the
Emerson Hotel. Representing the
only non-professional newspaper, the confused intruders at
first felt greatly out of place;
but With the aid of accommodating hosts (and a few drinks.
) the
atmosphere was transformed
into one of congeniality.
The big buzz—apologies to
Sputniks I and II—was a sixfoot-two sandy-haired Scotsman
replete with charm, decked in
typical bow tie, tortoise-shell
glasses, and chimpanzee—NBC's
Dave Garroway of Today and
Monitor fame.
A Drunken Inception
Garroway, when asked how he
chanced to enter TV, replied, "I
got drunk playing bridge with a
young gal in search of guides for
NBC."
From the position of guide,
Dave advanced to announcer,
general-announcer, and eventually to the "11:60 Club," a
disc-jockey show
originating
from Chicago. Immediately fol-

rsg

lowing was the Dave Garroway
Show.
On January 14, 1952, was
launched the Today Show with
Dave as its focal point. This
show progressed to its present
status -among the unique shows
in TV today and is the reason
for Dave's presence in Baltimore.
Baltimore Origination
Approximately five months
ago, it was decided in the upper
echelons of NBC to begin a tour
among the various cities along
the Today network. Garroway's
show in Baltimore, Thursday
and Friday, originated from
WBAL-TV and featured filmed
sequences of Fort McHenry and
other points of interest in Baltimore. While the rest of the nation was getting a look at us,
Dave never got a chance to really get a view for himself; his
stay was marked by one press
reception after another.
Dave goes back to New York in
between shows to get a little rest.
In his leisure time, he, as are
many other average Americans,
is active in various hobbies,
which include tinkering around
with his 1937 Jaguar, playing
golf or tennis, reading, or more
appropriately, playing bridge
over a friendly drink.

Greek legend ascribes its invention to Theseus, Homer
sang of it in the Iliad,.and Johns Hopkins is watching it
slowly fade out of the picture.
Wrestling's chances of survival at Hopkins appear
slim. At a meeting of all prospective wrestling candidates
on Thursday, November 7, Athletic Director Marshall
Turner stated the following conditions: 1. This year
Hopkins will have no scheduled matches and might get a
chance to participate in the Mason-Dixon Conference
Tournament. 2. Next year there will be no scheduled
matches and Hopkins will probably enter the M-D tourney.
3. In 1959-'60 there will be scheduled matches if sufficient
interest is shown.
When asked to comment on the situation, Senior Bob
Partridge, a varsity letterman and former member of the
team, said, "It looks as though the future of wrestling at
Hopkins lies in the hands of the freshmen and sophomores
Apparently full scale wrestling will not be present on the
Hopkins sports scene for several years, due to apathy
on the part of the student body here, the difficulties in
rescheduling teams once they have been dropped, and the
general hesitancy of the athletic department. With only
fourteen upperclassmen turning out for the meeting, it
doesn't look as though we will be able to field an eightman team in the Mason-Dixon tournament even if we
should be lucky enough to be able to participate. However,
I think that if student interest is such that we can field
an eight-man varsity and an eight-man freshman team,
the athletic director is obligated to try to schedule some
regular meets next year. It would be placing an almost
unbearable burden against the future of wrestling at
Hopkins if the greatest offer would only be the possibility
of entering the Mason-Dixon tournament for the next
two years."
Little encouragement is being offered those who have
indicated their desire to wrestle at Hopkins on the intercollegiate level. At best, the seniors might get into the
Mason-Dixon tournament after practicing for a season.
The juniors have the added incentive of probable
participation in the M-D tournament after two full seasons
of practice.
Should they stick it out for three years, the sophomores will probably be able to compete in dual meets
their senior year.
The freshmen will not be able to earn their freshman
numerals by wrestling. However, they are fairly assured
of a chance to earn varsity letters their junior year if
enough interest is shown by the students in the classes
preceding and following them.
Turner said that anyone that goes out for a sport
to earn a letter is not wanted. Are those who wrestle to
receive no recognition?

NEWS -LETTER

Jay Harriers Romp
In Double Encounter
The Hopkins varsity CrossCountry team beat both Towson
State Teachers' College and
Washington College in a double
meet last Tuesday. The Jays
beat Towson 15 to 45 low score
wins and Washington 19 to 37.
The double meet was necessitated by the fact that the
regularly scheduled meets had
previously been called off due
to illness. Although all three
schools started simultaneously
the scoring was recorded on the

basis of only two schools at a
time.
The best score for the meet
was
recorded
by
Hopkins'
Morris Jones, who ran the three
mile course in 17:03.3 Also
scoring for Coach Brown's harriers were Gene Harshman,
Charlie Ginsberg, Ernie Boatman, and John Brewer.
The Jays lost to Swarthmore
last Saturday 37-22. Dan Denhardt of Swarthmore was first
across the line followed by
Hopkins' Morris Jones.

National Award
To Dr. Strauss
The Johns Hopkins chapter
of Phi Epsilon Pi presented Dr.
William Strauss last Sunday
night with an award for outstanding achievements in his
scientific and community works.
Dr. Strauss is Professor of
Anatomy at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School and has been
associated with the university
for 25 years. He helped found
the Hopkins chapter of Phi Epsilon Pi in 1921.

achievement
award was presented to Dr.
Strauss by Vigdor Cavelier, president of the national fraternity,

—

Career opportunities at Du Pont are
greater today than ever before because of the Company's continued
growth. In 1957, Du Pont's sales
were at the $2 billion level. Four new
plants were being built. New research
programs were being launched, and
new products were moving into the
production and marketing stages. All
of these developments tend to broaden
opportunities at Du Pont for the
young scientist and engineer.
ALL KINDS OF ENGINEERS
Students with chemical engineering
and chemistry degrees are needed, of
course. But the opportunities are
equally great for students majoring
in many other fields. And the type of
work for these men varies greatly.
Among other things:
Mechanical engineers work in re-

search and development as well as in
plant engineering and production
supervision.
Metallurgical engineers conduct
studies in metal fatigue and corrosion
and engage in fundamental research
into the nature and properties of
elements.
4
7
,
0144

Civil engineers have many assignments, including design and supervision of the construction of Du Pont
plants and laboratories.
Men studying for degrees in electrical, mining, petroleum, industrial and
many other specialized fields of engineering will find equally challenging
outlets for their talents at Du Pont.
If you're interested in finding full
scope for your ability, Du Pont offers
you plenty of opportunity.

Du Pont Training Tailored to Individual
Each of Du Pont's operating departments has its own training program
because each has special requirements. But both formal and informal
programs are tailored to the interests
and needs of the individual.
Generally, you go to work on an
assignment at once and start learning
right away. This headstart on responsibility is an important factor in your
progress. Based on your qualifications, you're given one segment of a
project to tackle almost immediately.
You learn quickly and informally in
consultation with your supervisor and
other engineers on the same project.
This trainin'g is supplemented by frequent meetings, seminars, studies of
plant operations and procedures.
And since Du Pont is interested in
the progress of the individual, your

performance is evaluated at regular
intervals by your supervisor. These
discussions bring out your strong and
weak points and together you work
out a program for improvement. This
training and evaluation continues
year after year as you advance in
the Company.
SEND FOR INFORMATION BOOKLET
Booklets on jobs at Du Pont are
yours for the asking. Subjects
include: mechanical, civil, metallurgical, chemical, electrical, instrumentation and industrial
engineers at DuPont; atomic
energy, technical sales, research
and development. Name the subject that interests you in a letter
to Du Pont, 2494-B Nuunours
Building, Wilmington 98, Del.

Dr. Joseph Kaplan, chairman
of the United States commission
in the International Geophysical
Year, will speak in Shriver Hall,
November 20, at 8:00 p.m. under the co-sponsorship of the
Hopkins chapter of the Society
of American Military Engineers
and its Baltimore parent organization.

affiliation with a number of

Correspondence
Dear Editors:
I think it would be a ridiculous
proposal to assure every student
who goes out for a school team
a time to play. I read in the
last sports editorial "many who
would not consider . . . would
be more willing if they were
assured of playing." These are
the people we don't want anyhow.
What we want is the fellow
who goes out for the love of the
game and the will to win, with-out guarantees that he play a
certain amount or other assurances.
If there were guarantees, every
Tom, Joe, and Harry, who
wanted to look good in front of
the women, would go out for the
team, throw in a few halfhearted days of practice, and
presto, he's in (according to that
system of guarantees).
Think of the fix that would
put our team in. People who fear

that they won't play can always
join an independent or fraternal
team anyway.
If you try to substitute the
need to win for a need of total
participation, then you are exchanging a trained team of men
who mean business for a bunch
of babies, and turning what may
have been a good, tough, wellplayed ball game into a ludicrous
farce. When you take the emphasis off the need to win, you
cut -Clown the mean, fighting,
rocky spirit of the team. If you
don't play to win, why keep
score? Can you imagine the
cheer of Hopkins changing from
"Let's Beat F & M" to "Let's
Play F & M"?
To me, winning means a lot. A
tough, ferocious, rugged, punching, fiery game makes winning
even sweeter.
Martin G. Lichtenstein

Two weeks ago, two features
writers attended—rather crashed
—a press reception given at the
Emerson Hotel. Representing the
only non-professional newspaper, the confused intruders at
first felt greatly out of place;
but With the aid of accommodating hosts (and a few drinks.
) the
atmosphere was transformed
into one of congeniality.
The big buzz—apologies to
Sputniks I and II—was a sixfoot-two sandy-haired Scotsman
replete with charm, decked in
typical bow tie, tortoise-shell
glasses, and chimpanzee—NBC's
Dave Garroway of Today and
Monitor fame.
A Drunken Inception
Garroway, when asked how he
chanced to enter TV, replied, "I
got drunk playing bridge with a
young gal in search of guides for
NBC."
From the position of guide,
Dave advanced to announcer,
general-announcer, and eventually to the "11:60 Club," a
disc-jockey show
originating
from Chicago. Immediately fol-

rsg

lowing was the Dave Garroway
Show.
On January 14, 1952, was
launched the Today Show with
Dave as its focal point. This
show progressed to its present
status -among the unique shows
in TV today and is the reason
for Dave's presence in Baltimore.
Baltimore Origination
Approximately five months
ago, it was decided in the upper
echelons of NBC to begin a tour
among the various cities along
the Today network. Garroway's
show in Baltimore, Thursday
and Friday, originated from
WBAL-TV and featured filmed
sequences of Fort McHenry and
other points of interest in Baltimore. While the rest of the nation was getting a look at us,
Dave never got a chance to really get a view for himself; his
stay was marked by one press
reception after another.
Dave goes back to New York in
between shows to get a little rest.
In his leisure time, he, as are
many other average Americans,
is active in various hobbies,
which include tinkering around
with his 1937 Jaguar, playing
golf or tennis, reading, or more
appropriately, playing bridge
over a friendly drink.

Greek legend ascribes its invention to Theseus, Homer
sang of it in the Iliad,.and Johns Hopkins is watching it
slowly fade out of the picture.
Wrestling's chances of survival at Hopkins appear
slim. At a meeting of all prospective wrestling candidates
on Thursday, November 7, Athletic Director Marshall
Turner stated the following conditions: 1. This year
Hopkins will have no scheduled matches and might get a
chance to participate in the Mason-Dixon Conference
Tournament. 2. Next year there will be no scheduled
matches and Hopkins will probably enter the M-D tourney.
3. In 1959-'60 there will be scheduled matches if sufficient
interest is shown.
When asked to comment on the situation, Senior Bob
Partridge, a varsity letterman and former member of the
team, said, "It looks as though the future of wrestling at
Hopkins lies in the hands of the freshmen and sophomores
Apparently full scale wrestling will not be present on the
Hopkins sports scene for several years, due to apathy
on the part of the student body here, the difficulties in
rescheduling teams once they have been dropped, and the
general hesitancy of the athletic department. With only
fourteen upperclassmen turning out for the meeting, it
doesn't look as though we will be able to field an eightman team in the Mason-Dixon tournament even if we
should be lucky enough to be able to participate. However,
I think that if student interest is such that we can field
an eight-man varsity and an eight-man freshman team,
the athletic director is obligated to try to schedule some
regular meets next year. It would be placing an almost
unbearable burden against the future of wrestling at
Hopkins if the greatest offer would only be the possibility
of entering the Mason-Dixon tournament for the next
two years."
Little encouragement is being offered those who have
indicated their desire to wrestle at Hopkins on the intercollegiate level. At best, the seniors might get into the
Mason-Dixon tournament after practicing for a season.
The juniors have the added incentive of probable
participation in the M-D tournament after two full seasons
of practice.
Should they stick it out for three years, the sophomores will probably be able to compete in dual meets
their senior year.
The freshmen will not be able to earn their freshman
numerals by wrestling. However, they are fairly assured
of a chance to earn varsity letters their junior year if
enough interest is shown by the students in the classes
preceding and following them.
Turner said that anyone that goes out for a sport
to earn a letter is not wanted. Are those who wrestle to
receive no recognition?

NEWS -LETTER

Jay Harriers Romp
In Double Encounter
The Hopkins varsity CrossCountry team beat both Towson
State Teachers' College and
Washington College in a double
meet last Tuesday. The Jays
beat Towson 15 to 45 low score
wins and Washington 19 to 37.
The double meet was necessitated by the fact that the
regularly scheduled meets had
previously been called off due
to illness. Although all three
schools started simultaneously
the scoring was recorded on the

basis of only two schools at a
time.
The best score for the meet
was
recorded
by
Hopkins'
Morris Jones, who ran the three
mile course in 17:03.3 Also
scoring for Coach Brown's harriers were Gene Harshman,
Charlie Ginsberg, Ernie Boatman, and John Brewer.
The Jays lost to Swarthmore
last Saturday 37-22. Dan Denhardt of Swarthmore was first
across the line followed by
Hopkins' Morris Jones.

Phi Epsilon Pi
National Award
To Dr. Strauss
The Johns Hopkins chapter
of Phi Epsilon Pi presented Dr.
William Strauss last Sunday
night with an award for outstanding achievements in his
scientific and community works.
Dr. Strauss is Professor of
Anatomy at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School and has been
associated with the university
for 25 years. He helped found
the Hopkins chapter of Phi Epsilon Pi in 1921.
The national
achievement
award was presented to Dr.
Strauss by Vigdor Cavelier, president of the national fraternity,
in ceremonies held at the Suburban Club.

Career opportunities at Du Pont are
greater today than ever before because of the Company's continued
growth. In 1957, Du Pont's sales
were at the $2 billion level. Four new
plants were being built. New research
programs were being launched, and
new products were moving into the
production and marketing stages. All
of these developments tend to broaden
opportunities at Du Pont for the
young scientist and engineer.
ALL KINDS OF ENGINEERS
Students with chemical engineering
and chemistry degrees are needed, of
course. But the opportunities are
equally great for students majoring
in many other fields. And the type of
work for these men varies greatly.
Among other things:
Mechanical engineers work in re-

search and development as well as in
plant engineering and production
supervision.
Metallurgical engineers conduct
studies in metal fatigue and corrosion
and engage in fundamental research
into the nature and properties of
elements.

Civil engineers have many assignments, including design and supervision of the construction of Du Pont
plants and laboratories.
Men studying for degrees in electrical, mining, petroleum, industrial and
many other specialized fields of engineering will find equally challenging
outlets for their talents at Du Pont.
If you're interested in finding full
scope for your ability, Du Pont offers
you plenty of opportunity.

Du Pont Training Tailored to Individual
Each of Du Pont's operating departments has its own training program
because each has special requirements. But both formal and informal
programs are tailored to the interests
and needs of the individual.
Generally, you go to work on an
assignment at once and start learning
right away. This headstart on responsibility is an important factor in your
progress. Based on your qualifications, you're given one segment of a
project to tackle almost immediately.
You learn quickly and informally in
consultation with your supervisor and
other engineers on the same project.
This trainin'g is supplemented by frequent meetings, seminars, studies of
plant operations and procedures.
And since Du Pont is interested in
the progress of the individual, your

performance is evaluated at regular
intervals by your supervisor. These
discussions bring out your strong and
weak points and together you work
out a program for improvement. This
training and evaluation continues
year after year as you advance in
the Company.
SEND FOR INFORMATION BOOKLET
Booklets on jobs at Du Pont are
yours for the asking. Subjects
include: mechanical, civil, metallurgical, chemical, electrical, instrumentation and industrial
engineers at DuPont; atomic
energy, technical sales, research
and development. Name the subject that interests you in a letter
to Du Pont, 2494-B Nuunours
